Organism_Record.Function_Summary: FixJ, when activated by fixL, induces the expression of both nifA, required for activation of classical nif and fix genes, and fixK, required for fixN activation.

Funtion.Detail: Responds to a two-component sensor to initiate a change in cell state or activity. The activity of the response regulator is regulated by transfer of a phosphate from a histidine residue in the sensor, to an aspartate residue in the response regulator. Many but not all response regulators act as transcriptional regulators to elicit a response.
Any molecular function by which a gene product interacts selectively with DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid).

Interacting selectively and non-covalently with DNA of a specific nucleotide composition, e.g. GC-rich DNA binding, or with a specific sequence motif or type of DNA e.g. promotor binding or rDNA binding.
Protein that positively regulates either the transcription of one or more genes, or the translation of mRNA.
Interacting selectively and non-covalently with any metal ion.

Interacting selectively and non-covalently with a specific DNA sequence in order to modulate transcription. The transcription factor may or may not also interact selectively with a protein or macromolecular complex.
Funtion.Keyword: Sequence-specific DNA binding transcription factor activity

BioProcess.Detail: The cellular synthesis of either RNA on a template of DNA or DNA on a template of RNA.
Any process that modulates the frequency, rate or extent of the synthesis of either RNA on a template of DNA or DNA on a template of RNA.

A conserved series of molecular signals found in prokaryotes and eukaryotes; involves autophosphorylation of a histidine kinase and the transfer of the phosphate group to an aspartate that then acts as a phospho-donor to response regulator proteins.
The cellular synthesis of RNA on a template of DNA.

The process in which nitrogen is taken from its relatively inert molecular form (N2) in the atmosphere and converted into nitrogen compounds useful for other chemical processes, such as ammonia, nitrate and nitrogen dioxide.
